user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtTest_AddCommon:
```c
void UtTest_AddCommon(void (*Test)(void), void (*Setup)(void), void (*Teardown)(void), const char *TestName,
                      uint32 EntryType)
{
    UtTestDataBaseEntry_t UtTestDataBaseEntry;

    memset(&UtTestDataBaseEntry, 0, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry));
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Test     = Test;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Setup    = Setup;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Teardown = Teardown;
    if (TestName != NULL)
    {
        strncpy(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName, TestName, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName) - 1);
    }

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    UtList_Add(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, &UtTestDataBaseEntry, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry_t), EntryType);
    UT_BSP_Unlock();
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtTest_AddCommon:
typedef struct
{
    void (*Test)(void);
    void (*Setup)(void);
    void (*Teardown)(void);

    /* Note - the name entry should be long enough to support a GroupName.TestName pattern,
     * hence why it uses double the OS_MAX_API_NAME length */
    char TestName[OS_MAX_API_NAME * 2];
} UtTestDataBaseEntry_t
...
void UtList_Add(UtListHead_t *ListHead, void *Data, uint32 DataSize, uint32 Tag)
{
    UtListNode_t *TagHead;
    UtListNode_t *NewNode;

    TagHead = UtList_GetHead(ListHead, Tag);
    if (TagHead != NULL)
    {
        NewNode      = UtList_NewNode(Data, DataSize);
        NewNode->Tag = Tag;
        UtList_Insert_Before(TagHead, NewNode);
    }
}
...
UtAssert_Global_t UtAssert_Global
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: void UtList_Add(UtListHead_t *ListHead, void *Data, uint32 DataSize, uint32 Tag)
explanation: The listed fragments are places where pointer parameters that appear to be used only for reading (e.g. the Data argument passed to create a new list node, and the call to get the list head) are declared/used as non-const and therefore should be investigated for possible const-qualification. Other fragments do not need investigation for this rule: the Test/Setup/Teardown parameters are function pointers (not object data pointers) so const-qualification of the pointed-to function type is not applicable here; TestName is already declared const char *; the destination of strncpy and the local UtTestDataBaseEntry are objects intentionally modified; ListHead in UtList_Add and NewNode/Tag manipulations appear to modify the list/nodes (so those pointers should remain non-const). Consequently these other fragments are not suspected for Rule 8.13.
